canonical_explanation.text: Sound is produced by vibrating objects. When an object vibrates, it creates disturbances in the surrounding medium (solid, liquid, or gas) that travel as sound waves. Sound cannot travel through a vacuum because it needs a material medium to propagate. The frequency of a sound is the number of oscillations per second, measured in Hertz (Hz). The amplitude is the maximum displacement from the mean position. Loudness of sound depends on its amplitude — greater amplitude means louder sound. Pitch depends on frequency — higher frequency means higher pitch. The audible range for humans is 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz. Unwanted sound is called noise, while pleasant, rhythmic sound is called music. Noise pollution from various sources can harm health and should be controlled.
rules: Sound is produced by vibrating objects.
Sound requires a medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel — it cannot travel through vacuum.
Frequency: number of oscillations per second; SI unit is Hertz (Hz).
Amplitude: maximum displacement of a vibrating particle from its mean position.
Time period: time taken for one complete oscillation; T = 1/f.
Loudness depends on amplitude — greater amplitude means louder sound.
Pitch depends on frequency — higher frequency means higher pitch.
Audible range of human ear: 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz.
Sounds below 20 Hz are infrasonic; above 20,000 Hz are ultrasonic.
Noise pollution: unwanted sound that is harmful to health; caused by vehicles, loudspeakers, factories.

questions.question_text: Sound is produced by:
questions.explanation_correct: Sound is produced by vibrating objects. When an object vibrates, it disturbs the surrounding medium and creates sound waves that travel to our ears.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Stationary objects (B) do not produce sound — vibration is needed. Light waves (C) and heat energy (D) are different forms of energy. Sound is produced specifically by vibrating objects (A).

questions.question_text: Sound cannot travel through:
questions.explanation_correct: Sound cannot travel through a vacuum because sound needs a material medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to propagate. In a vacuum, there are no particles to transmit the vibrations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sound can travel through air (A), water (B), and steel (D) — all are material media. It cannot travel through vacuum (C) because there are no particles to carry the vibrations.

questions.question_text: In humans, sound is produced by the:

options.text: Vocal cords in the larynx (voice box)

questions.explanation_correct: In humans, sound is produced by the vibration of vocal cords (vocal folds) in the larynx (voice box). When air from the lungs passes over the stretched vocal cords, they vibrate and produce sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lungs (A) push air out but do not produce sound directly. The tongue (C) and teeth (D) help shape speech sounds but do not produce the initial sound. The vocal cords in the larynx (B) vibrate to produce sound.

questions.question_text: When you pluck a guitar string, you hear sound because:

options.text: The string vibrates and creates sound waves in the air

questions.explanation_correct: When you pluck a guitar string, it vibrates rapidly. These vibrations disturb the surrounding air particles, creating sound waves that travel through the air to your ears.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The string does not change colour (A). The guitar does not get heavier (C). Light bouncing off (D) is not related to sound production. The vibrating string (B) creates sound waves in the air.

questions.question_text: An astronaut on the Moon cannot hear another astronaut shouting nearby because:

options.text: There is too much gravity on the Moon
The Moon has no atmosphere (vacuum), and sound cannot travel through vacuum
Sound travels faster on the Moon
The astronaut's ears do not work on the Moon

questions.explanation_correct: The Moon has no atmosphere, so its surface is essentially a vacuum. Since sound requires a medium (like air) to travel, it cannot propagate in the vacuum on the Moon. Astronauts use radio communication instead.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Moon's gravity (A) does not prevent sound. Sound doesn't travel at all in vacuum, so faster/slower is irrelevant (C). Ears work fine on the Moon (D). The absence of atmosphere (B) means no medium for sound to travel through.

questions.question_text: The number of oscillations per second of a vibrating object is called its:
questions.explanation_correct: Frequency is the number of oscillations (vibrations) per second. It is measured in Hertz (Hz). A higher frequency means more vibrations per second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amplitude (A) is the maximum displacement from the mean position. Time period (B) is the time for one complete oscillation. Wavelength (D) is the distance between two consecutive crests or troughs. Frequency (C) is the number of oscillations per second.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of frequency is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of frequency is Hertz (Hz), named after Heinrich Hertz. One Hertz means one oscillation per second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Second (A) is the unit of time. Metre (B) is the unit of length. Decibel (D) is the unit of loudness. The correct unit of frequency is Hertz (C).

questions.question_text: Amplitude of a vibration is:

options.text: The number of vibrations per second
The maximum displacement from the mean position
The time for one complete vibration

questions.explanation_correct: Amplitude is the maximum displacement of a vibrating object from its mean (rest) position. It determines the loudness of the sound — greater amplitude means louder sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Number of vibrations per second (A) is frequency. Time for one vibration (C) is time period. Speed (D) is a different quantity. Amplitude (B) is the maximum displacement from mean position.

questions.question_text: If a pendulum completes 20 oscillations in 10 seconds, its frequency is:
questions.explanation_correct: Frequency = Number of oscillations / Time = 20 / 10 = 2 Hz. The pendulum completes 2 oscillations per second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Frequency = Number of oscillations / Time. So 20 oscillations / 10 seconds = 2 Hz (B). Options A (10 Hz), C (20 Hz), and D (0.5 Hz) result from incorrect calculations.

questions.question_text: If the frequency of a sound wave is 500 Hz, its time period is:
questions.explanation_correct: Time period T = 1/frequency = 1/500 = 0.002 seconds. The time for one complete oscillation is 0.002 seconds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Time period = 1/frequency. So T = 1/500 = 0.002 seconds (B). Options A (500 s), C (2 s), and D (0.5 s) are incorrect calculations.

questions.question_text: Sound can travel through solids, liquids, and gases.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Sound can travel through all three states of matter — solids, liquids, and gases. It only cannot travel through vacuum because there are no particles to transmit vibrations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Sound can propagate through any material medium — solid, liquid, or gas. Placing your ear on a railway track to hear a distant train is an example of sound through solids.

questions.question_text: The pitch of a sound increases when its frequency decreases.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Pitch is directly proportional to frequency — when frequency increases, pitch also increases, and when frequency decreases, pitch decreases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pitch depends directly on frequency. Higher frequency produces higher pitch, and lower frequency produces lower pitch. The statement incorrectly says pitch increases when frequency decreases.

questions.question_text: Sounds with frequencies below 20 Hz can be heard by the human ear.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The human ear can only hear sounds in the range of 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz (audible range). Sounds below 20 Hz are called infrasonic and cannot be heard by humans.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sounds below 20 Hz are infrasonic and are below the audible range of the human ear. The human ear can only detect frequencies between 20 Hz and 20,000 Hz.

questions.question_text: Sound is produced by ___ objects.
questions.explanation_correct: Sound is produced by vibrating objects. When an object vibrates, it creates disturbances in the surrounding medium that are perceived as sound by our ears.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'vibrating'. An object must vibrate (move back and forth rapidly) to produce sound waves.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of frequency is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of frequency is Hertz (Hz), named after the German physicist Heinrich Hertz. 1 Hz = 1 oscillation per second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Hertz'. Frequency, which measures the number of oscillations per second, is measured in Hertz (Hz).

questions.question_text: The audible range of the human ear is from 20 Hz to ___ Hz.
questions.explanation_correct: The human ear can hear sounds in the frequency range of 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz. Sounds below 20 Hz are infrasonic and above 20,000 Hz are ultrasonic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is '20000'. The upper limit of human hearing is 20,000 Hz (20 kHz). Sounds above this frequency are called ultrasonic.

questions.question_text: The loudness of a sound depends on its:
questions.explanation_correct: The loudness of a sound depends on its amplitude. Greater amplitude means a louder sound, while smaller amplitude means a softer sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Frequency (A) determines pitch, not loudness. Speed (C) depends on the medium. Wavelength (D) is related to frequency. Loudness depends on amplitude (B) — the greater the amplitude, the louder the sound.

questions.question_text: The pitch of a sound is determined by its:
questions.explanation_correct: The pitch of a sound is determined by its frequency. Higher frequency produces a higher-pitched (shrill) sound, and lower frequency produces a lower-pitched (flat or deep) sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amplitude (A) determines loudness. Speed (B) depends on the medium. Medium (D) affects the speed. Pitch is determined by frequency (C) — higher frequency means higher pitch.

questions.question_text: A drum produces a loud sound when hit hard. This is because hitting hard:

options.text: Changes the pitch of the sound

questions.explanation_correct: When a drum is hit hard, the membrane vibrates with a larger amplitude. Since loudness depends on amplitude, a greater amplitude produces a louder sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hitting harder does not significantly change the frequency (A), pitch (C), or time period (D). It increases the amplitude (B) of vibration, resulting in a louder sound.

questions.question_text: A mosquito produces a higher-pitched buzz than a lion's roar because the mosquito's wings vibrate at a:
questions.explanation_correct: A mosquito's wings vibrate at a much higher frequency than the vocal cords of a lion. Since pitch depends on frequency, the higher frequency of the mosquito's wing beats produces a higher-pitched sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lower frequency (A) would produce a lower pitch. Higher amplitude (B) would make it louder, not higher-pitched. Lower amplitude (D) would make it softer. The higher pitch is due to higher frequency (C).

questions.question_text: The range of frequencies that the human ear can hear is:
questions.explanation_correct: The audible range of the human ear is from 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz. Sounds within this range can be perceived by normal human hearing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The range 1-100 Hz (A) is too narrow. 20,000-50,000 Hz (C) is ultrasonic. 0-20 Hz (D) is infrasonic. The correct audible range is 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz (B).

questions.question_text: Unpleasant and disturbing sound is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Noise is unpleasant, disturbing, or unwanted sound. Unlike music, which is pleasant and rhythmic, noise has no regular pattern and can be harmful to hearing and health.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Music (A), melody (C), and rhythm (D) are all related to pleasant, organized sounds. Unpleasant and disturbing sound is called noise (B).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a source of noise pollution?
questions.explanation_correct: Loud vehicle horns are a major source of noise pollution in cities. They produce high-intensity, unpleasant sounds that can cause hearing problems, stress, and sleep disturbance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Whispering (A), birdsong (B), and gentle breeze (D) are not sources of noise pollution. Loud vehicle horns (C) produce excessive noise that contributes to noise pollution.

questions.question_text: Noise pollution can lead to all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: Noise pollution causes hearing loss, sleeplessness, and high blood pressure, among other health problems. It does NOT improve concentration — in fact, it reduces concentration and causes irritability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hearing loss (A), sleeplessness (B), and high blood pressure (D) are all harmful effects of noise pollution. Noise pollution reduces concentration; it does not improve it (C).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a way to reduce noise pollution?

options.text: Increasing the number of vehicles on the road

questions.explanation_correct: Planting trees along roads helps reduce noise pollution because trees absorb and block sound waves, acting as natural sound barriers. This is an effective and environmentally friendly method.
questions.explanation_incorrect: More vehicles (A) and louder speakers (C) increase noise. Running factories at night (D) doesn't reduce noise — it just shifts the timing. Planting trees (B) is a valid method to reduce noise pollution.

questions.question_text: If you put your ear on a railway track, you can hear an approaching train before the sound reaches you through the air. This is because:

options.text: The track vibrates more than air
Sound travels faster through solids (steel tracks) than through air

questions.explanation_correct: Sound travels faster through solids than through air because the particles in a solid are more closely packed, allowing vibrations to transfer more quickly. Steel tracks carry sound much faster than air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The track does not vibrate more than air (A) or amplify sound (C). Air does not block sound completely (D). The reason is that sound travels faster through solids (B) like steel than through air.

questions.question_text: The time period of a vibrating object is 0.05 seconds. Its frequency is:
questions.explanation_correct: Frequency = 1 / Time period = 1 / 0.05 = 20 Hz. The object vibrates 20 times per second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Frequency = 1/T = 1/0.05 = 20 Hz. Options A (0.05 Hz), B (5 Hz), and D (50 Hz) are results of incorrect calculations.

questions.question_text: A thin, tight string on a guitar produces a sound of higher pitch compared to a thick, loose string because the thin string vibrates at a:
questions.explanation_correct: A thin, tight string vibrates at a higher frequency than a thick, loose string. Since pitch depends on frequency, a higher frequency produces a higher-pitched sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lower frequency (A) produces lower pitch. Higher amplitude (C) affects loudness, not pitch. Speed (D) is not directly relevant. The higher pitch comes from higher frequency (B) of the thin, tight string.

questions.question_text: Sound travels faster through water than through air.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Sound travels faster through water than through air because water particles are more closely packed than air particles, allowing sound vibrations to be transmitted more quickly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sound travels faster in denser media. Since water is denser than air, sound travels faster through water than through air.

questions.question_text: A woman's voice generally has a higher pitch than a man's voice because of higher frequency.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. A woman's vocal cords are generally shorter and thinner than a man's, causing them to vibrate at a higher frequency. Higher frequency results in a higher-pitched sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Women's shorter, thinner vocal cords vibrate at higher frequencies, producing a naturally higher-pitched voice compared to men's deeper voices.

questions.question_text: Noise pollution can cause temporary or permanent hearing loss.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Prolonged exposure to loud noise can damage the delicate structures in the ear, leading to temporary hearing impairment or even permanent hearing loss.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Exposure to loud sounds above 80 dB for prolonged periods can cause both temporary and permanent hearing damage.

questions.question_text: Loudness of sound depends on its ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The loudness of a sound depends on its amplitude. Greater amplitude means louder sound, and smaller amplitude means softer sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'amplitude'. Loudness is directly related to amplitude — the greater the amplitude of vibration, the louder the sound produced.

questions.question_text: Sound cannot travel through ___ because there are no particles to transmit vibrations.
questions.explanation_correct: Sound cannot travel through vacuum because sound needs a material medium (particles) to propagate. In a vacuum, there are no particles to carry the vibrations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'vacuum'. Sound requires a medium with particles (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel. A vacuum has no particles, so sound cannot propagate through it.

questions.question_text: Which of the following sounds is considered music?

options.text: Sound of a tabla being played rhythmically

questions.explanation_correct: The rhythmic sound of a tabla is considered music because it has a regular pattern, is pleasant to hear, and is produced with skill and rhythm. Music consists of organized, pleasing sounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Car horns (A), construction noise (C), and bursting crackers (D) produce irregular, harsh sounds classified as noise. A tabla played rhythmically (B) produces organized, pleasant music.

questions.question_text: An object vibrates 600 times in 30 seconds. What is its frequency and time period?
questions.explanation_correct: Frequency = 600 oscillations / 30 seconds = 20 Hz. Time period = 1/frequency = 1/20 = 0.05 seconds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: F = 600/30 = 20 Hz, and T = 1/20 = 0.05 s. Option B (30 Hz) divides by 20 instead. Option C (600 Hz) doesn't divide. Option D (2 Hz) seems random. The correct answer is A.

questions.question_text: Which of the following experiments best demonstrates that sound needs a medium to travel?

options.text: Placing a ringing bell in a jar and removing air gradually

questions.explanation_correct: When a ringing bell is placed in a jar and air is gradually pumped out, the sound becomes fainter and eventually inaudible. This demonstrates that sound needs a medium (air) to travel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Playing drums (A), plucking strings (C), and clapping (D) all produce sound but don't prove that a medium is necessary. The bell jar experiment (B) directly shows that removing the medium (air) stops sound from reaching us.

questions.question_text: Two sounds have the same frequency but different amplitudes. They will differ in their:
questions.explanation_correct: Since the frequency is the same, both sounds will have the same pitch and time period. Since they have different amplitudes, they will differ in loudness — the one with greater amplitude will be louder.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same frequency means same pitch (A) and same time period (D). Speed (C) depends on the medium. Different amplitudes means different loudness (B).

questions.question_text: Which of the following measures can help control noise pollution?

options.text: Using loudspeakers at full volume during festivals
Installing silencers in vehicles and using ear plugs in noisy areas
Building more factories near residential areas

questions.explanation_correct: Silencers reduce noise from vehicle exhausts, and ear plugs protect individuals from harmful noise exposure. These are practical measures to control noise pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Loudspeakers at full volume (A) add to noise pollution. Factories near homes (C) increase noise. Removing trees (D) removes natural sound barriers. Only installing silencers and using ear plugs (B) helps control noise pollution.

questions.question_text: A baby's cry has a higher pitch than an adult's speech because:

options.text: The baby's cry has greater amplitude
The baby's vocal cords vibrate at a higher frequency
The baby produces more sound energy
Sound travels faster from a baby

questions.explanation_correct: A baby has shorter and thinner vocal cords that vibrate at a higher frequency. Since pitch depends on frequency, the baby's higher-frequency vibrations produce a higher-pitched sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Greater amplitude (A) affects loudness, not pitch. Producing more energy (C) relates to loudness. Speed of sound (D) doesn't depend on the source. Higher pitch is due to higher frequency (B) of the baby's vocal cords.

questions.question_text: When you touch a vibrating tuning fork to the surface of water, you see ripples. This demonstrates that:

options.text: The tuning fork is transferring its vibrations to the water

questions.explanation_correct: The ripples in water show that the vibrating tuning fork is transferring its vibrations (energy) to the water. This demonstrates how sound energy is transmitted through a medium by setting particles into vibration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water itself doesn't produce the sound (A). It doesn't absorb all sound (C). Sound doesn't only travel through water (D). The ripples show the tuning fork transferring vibrations to water (B).

questions.question_text: If you tighten a guitar string and pluck it, compared to the loose string, the sound will have:
questions.explanation_correct: Tightening a guitar string increases its tension, which makes it vibrate at a higher frequency. Higher frequency produces a higher pitch. This is how musicians tune their instruments.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A tighter string vibrates faster (higher frequency), so the pitch increases, not decreases (A). Tightening doesn't reduce loudness (B). The sound definitely changes (D). Tightening produces a higher pitch (C).

questions.question_text: Hospitals, schools, and courts usually have 'Silence Zone' signs because:

options.text: People in these places do not like any sound
Noise can disturb patients, students, and court proceedings
Sound cannot travel inside these buildings
These buildings are made of special sound-proof material

questions.explanation_correct: Silence zones are designated around hospitals, schools, and courts because noise can disturb patients who need rest, students who are studying, and court proceedings that require concentration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It's not that people dislike all sound (A). Sound can travel inside (C). These buildings aren't necessarily soundproof (D). Noise needs to be minimised (B) to protect patients, enable learning, and allow court proceedings.

questions.question_text: If the time period of a vibrating object is halved, its frequency doubles.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Frequency = 1 / Time period. If time period is halved (T/2), frequency = 1/(T/2) = 2/T = 2 times the original frequency. So the frequency doubles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since frequency = 1/T, halving T gives f = 1/(T/2) = 2/T, which is double the original frequency. The statement is true.

questions.question_text: The pitch of a sound is determined by the ___ of vibration.
questions.explanation_correct: Pitch depends on frequency. A higher frequency of vibration produces a higher-pitched (shriller) sound, while a lower frequency produces a lower-pitched (deeper) sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'frequency'. Pitch and frequency are directly related — increasing frequency raises the pitch.

questions.question_text: Unwanted or disturbing sound is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Noise is unwanted or disturbing sound that is unpleasant to the ear. Excessive noise in the environment is called noise pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'noise'. Unlike music, which is pleasant and organized, noise is unwanted and disturbing sound.

questions.question_text: In which medium does sound travel the fastest?
questions.explanation_correct: Sound travels fastest through solids like steel because the particles are most closely packed, allowing vibrations to transfer most quickly. The order is: Solids > Liquids > Gases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sound cannot travel through vacuum (D). It travels through air (A) and water (B) but slowest and moderately fast respectively. Steel (C), being a solid with closely packed particles, allows the fastest sound propagation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes music as compared to noise?

options.text: Music has irregular vibrations while noise has regular vibrations
Music has a regular pattern and is pleasant, while noise is irregular and unpleasant
Music and noise are the same
Music is always louder than noise

questions.explanation_correct: Music has a regular pattern of vibrations and is pleasant to the ear, while noise has irregular vibrations and is unpleasant or disturbing. This is the key difference between music and noise.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the description. Music and noise are not the same (C). Music is not necessarily louder (D). The correct distinction is that music is regular and pleasant, while noise is irregular and unpleasant (B).

questions.question_text: The relationship between time period (T) and frequency (f) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Time period (T) and frequency (f) are inversely related: T = 1/f. If the frequency increases, the time period decreases, and vice versa.
questions.explanation_incorrect: T does not equal f (A), f² (C), or 2f (D). The correct relationship is T = 1/f (B), meaning time period and frequency are inversely proportional.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a harmful effect of noise pollution?
questions.explanation_correct: Better sleep quality is NOT an effect of noise pollution. In fact, noise pollution causes sleep disturbance, not better sleep. Hearing impairment, anxiety, stress, and high blood pressure are all harmful effects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hearing impairment (A), anxiety/stress (B), and high blood pressure (D) are all harmful effects. Better sleep quality (C) is NOT an effect — noise pollution actually disrupts sleep.

questions.question_text: The time taken for one complete oscillation is called the ___ of the vibration.
questions.explanation_correct: The time period is the time taken to complete one full oscillation or vibration. It is the reciprocal of frequency: T = 1/f.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'time period'. It represents the duration of one complete oscillation and is measured in seconds.
